legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Annual Business Survey

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Annual Business Survey (ABS).
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.
You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
You can save or print a copy of your answers for your records at the end of this survey.

contents.description: You can preview the questions and some of the guidance before starting the survey. There is more detailed guidance available when you start the survey.
This survey is a key resource for understanding the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
View the survey information (this link opens in a new tab)
This survey has the following sections:

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's income.
This includes:
This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.
This includes expenditure on:

list: rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the Government

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding the value of stocks held by your business at the start of the reporting period, and at the end of the reporting period.

This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of goods.
This section asks for information regarding your business's Research and Development.

list: The information you supply, helps to measure the UK economy and is used by the government to determine economic policy. The ABS also influences decisions on company and personal taxation, and interest rates.
The statistics produced help to improve the overall quality of National Accounts and the measurement of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) (this link opens in a new tab)

In addition to the National Accounts, the ABS is also used by the Scottish Government and Welsh Government in the compilation of both regional country specific Input and Output tables and Indices of Production.
It also provides a major contribution to the Blue Book, which is produced annually by our National Accounts Team and used to inform HM Treasury in managing economic policy.
View the latest publication produced from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)

sections.title: How to complete and reporting period

summary.page_title: How to complete and reporting period summary

blocks.page_title: How to complete and reporting period

content.title: How to complete and reporting period

contents.description: The ABS collects information to better understand the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
Please read the following information before starting the survey.

list: Questions in this survey ask for figures either for GB or the UK. Instructions will be provided for each section to know which figures to provide.

Questions that ask for UK data should relate to business activity in England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland, but excludes the Channel Islands and Isle of Man. For GB data, exclude Northern Ireland.
Please round your figures to the nearest £1,000.
If you need to report negative figures for a question, please enter a '0' and include them in your comments at the end of the survey.
Refer to additional guidance accompanying each question for more information.

contents.description: View the survey information (this link opens in a new tab)

contents.title: What activity to include in this survey

contents.description: Any activity outside the UK lasting for more than one year should be excluded from this questionnaire, except all installation activities outside the UK, which should be included regardless of the length of period of the work carried out.

Any work done in connection with overseas contracts where employees travel abroad regularly for short periods should be included and any overseas activity which is deemed to be capital expenditure in that country should be excluded.

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

title.text: Are you able to report for the calendar year {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}?

description: Your return should cover the calendar year 2023.

contents.description: Did your business only trade for part of the year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'
Does your business need to report for a different calendar year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'

options.label: Yes, I can report for this period
options.value: Yes, I can report for this period

options.label: No, I need to report for a different period
options.value: No, I need to report for a different period

blocks.page_title: Calendar year reporting period

in: Yes, I can report for this period

question.title: What dates will you be reporting for?
description: If figures are not available for the calendar year 2023, your return should relate to a 12 month business year that ends between 6 April 2023 and 5 April 2024.

contents.description: Did your business only trade for part of the year?
Please provide figures for the period in which you were trading.
Has your business commenced trading during 2023?
Your return should cover the period from the commencement of your business until 31 December 2023 or, alternatively, any date up to 5 April 2024.
Has your business ceased trading during 2023?
Your return should cover the period 1 January 2023 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

answers.label: From
To

blocks.page_title: Alternative reporting period
Income section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's income.
This includes:

The commodity breakdown should relate to sales through retail shops, petrol filling stations, roundsmen's depots, stalls, door-to-door, mail order, party plan or automatic vending machines. If you do not have exact records of sales or receipts under particular headings within the commodity breakdown, make the best estimate you can, heading by heading. The list is the minimum needed to satisfy this range of requirements as we are conscious of the burden placed on business and try to keep it to a minimum.
This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s total turnover?

contents.description: Include:

list: progress payments on work in progress
commission on rental from businesses trading on your premises, for example, a shop within a shop

contents.description: Exclude:

This refers to the total amount receivable in respect of invoices raised during the period of the return, from the sale of goods and services. Figures should be given gross of indirect taxes, duties and levies, including VAT, invoiced to the customer.

answers.label: Total turnover
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: VAT unless paying VAT under the Margin Scheme for second-hand goods, works of art, antiques and collectors' items
all sales of goods, except fixed capital assets, including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing

provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
work done on customers’ materials including the value of any additional materials added
income from construction activity, even if subcontracted
income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
income from postal activities and Post Office Ltd
commission from sales of telephone top-up cards
income derived from the renting of property
amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights and so on
receipts from government for goods and services supplied free, or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Services and similar public services
transport, insurance and packaging charges, less amounts for returnable containers, invoiced by your business even if invoiced separately

for commission work, for example where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange, such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases
service charges for credit provided but not interest charges
the value of vouchers, tokens and coupons used by customers as a means of payment, but not the sale of such vouchers and so on to customers
income from retail sales over the internet where you hold title to the goods sold
commission from sales over the internet where you do not hold title to the goods sold

contents.description: Exclude:

list: concession sales where you do not hold title to the goods sold
income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
the sale of vehicles previously treated as capital assets during the period
amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks, copyrights and so on
subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union (EU)
income derived from the renting of land, if recorded separately within your accounts
income recorded as 'other operating income' in your accounts
all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates, record turnover net of these
sales by other businesses operating on your premises
interest payments received and other similar income
amounts arising from donations and fundraising activities
the full value of any transfer fees received

blocks.page_title: Total turnover

title.text: Of the {total_turnover} total turnover, what was your business's value of VAT?

answers.label: Value of VAT
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: VAT value

title.text: Of {total_turnover} total turnover, what was your business's income from the retail sale of goods to the general public?

description:
Where exact figures for wholesale and retail split are not available, informed estimates are acceptable.

Please include examples of retail turnover in the comments box at the end of the questionnaire, if applicable.

contents.description: Include:

list: sales of goods direct to the general public, and not to businesses, for personal or household use
sale of petroleum products to which you hold title. Petrol filling stations who do not hold title to the petrol sales should only include fees receivable and not the full value of petrol sales

contents.description: Exclude:

list: catering activity such as sales of prepared food and drink
rental from businesses trading on your premises, for example, a shop within a shop

answers.label: Income from the retail sale of goods to the general public
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: commission from sales of telephone top-up cards
commission or rental from other businesses trading on your premises, for example, shop within a shop
commission from sales over the internet where you do not hold title to the goods sold

for commission work, where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
service charges for credit provided but not interest charges
receipts from government for goods and services supplied free, or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Service and similar public services
income from retail sales over the Internet where you hold title to the goods sold
over the counter supply of drugs, medicines and general supplies
installation services on domestic and household appliances, only when in combination with sale of goods
commission received on sales by other businesses operating on your premises, excluding the total value of the sale

contents.description: Exclude:

list: sales, repair and maintenance of motor vehicles, motorcycles, their parts and accessories
income from postal activities and Post Office Ltd
sales of services, for example, holidays, cinema and other tickets, and membership fees
turnover from work on the structure of a building, for example, decorating and plumbing
sales and maintenance of land and buildings
installation services on domestic and household appliances when not in combination with sale of goods

blocks.page_title: Turnover from the retail sale of goods to the general public

Commodity breakdown summary
blocks.title: We have calculated your business's commodity breakdown of retail turnover to be %(total)s. Is this correct?

title.text: Does {ru_name} produce goods or services that protect the environment?

contents.description: Include:
Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are produced by your business. For example:

list: production or installation of solar panels
waste collection, treatment and disposal services

contents.description: Exclude:
Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are used by your business. For example:

list: the use of energy saving light bulbs

blocks.page_title: Production of goods or services that protect the environment

question.title: What percentage of your business’s total turnover related to the production of environmental goods or services?
description: An informed estimate is acceptable.

blocks.page_title: Percentage of turnover related to production of environmental goods or services
Expenditure section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.
This includes expenditure on:

list: rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government

contents.description: This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s expenditure on employment costs?

description: Wages and salaries are defined as the total compensation in cash or in-kind payable to all employees. State the amount paid before deductions but less any amounts for which you are reimbursed from government sources.

contents.description: Include:

list: all overtime payments, bonuses and commissions
payments to those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on parental leave, on holiday, or on sick

the cost to the employer of all expenses and benefits in-kind. These include: assets transferred to employees such as cars, property, goods or other assets. Payments made on behalf of employees such as mileage allowances and fuel payments, unless the payments are in respect of travelling expenses. Subsidies to staff canteens, sports club membership, nurseries, playschemes, health insurance and so on
employment costs paid to workers employed by the UK company and workers employed who are based overseas. These costs should only reflect the installation services activity carried out outside the UK
contributions to pension funds, including lump sum contributions. Employers' pension contributions should represent actual net amounts rather than notional values
payments into pension funds providing retirement or death benefits for employees, including former employees or their dependents
redundancy and severance payments to employees, including golden handshakes
any 'signing on' fees paid to employees

contents.description: Exclude:

list: payments to working proprietors, partners, and executive directors not in receipt of a regular salary, fee, or commission
payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
top up of pension funds or withdrawals from pension funds
rebates received from National Insurance Redundancy Fund

contents.description: An employee is anyone aged 16 or over that your organisation pays directly from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme.
Include:

list: all workers such as permanent, temporary, casual and seasonal workers, paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on parental leave, on holiday, or on sick

contents.description: Exclude:

list: former employees only receiving a pension

answers.label: Expenditure on employment costs
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Expenditure on employment costs

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on purchases of goods bought for resale?
description: State the net full delivered cost of purchases made during the period of this return whether or not they were used or resold during that period. Valuation should be at full delivered cost. In the case of imports the cost should include import and excise duties, less drawback.

contents.description: Include:

list: any goods bought for resale without further processing, for example, merchanted goods, goods purchased and resold without modification

the cost of raw materials, such as flour used in an instore bakery, components, semi-manufactures, workshop and office materials, such as stationery and consumables, machine spares and packaging materials charged to you
any energy products bought for resale without further processing, for example, petroleum products including diesel, gas including LPG and hydrogen and solid fuels including coal, coke and charcoal
any goods bought on a ‘sale or return’ basis which were subsequently sold but exclude the cost of those returned unsold
carcasses that have been purchased in order to produce smaller cuts of meat
food and drink used in the preparation of meals, sandwiches and drinks, for example, food products used in an instore canteen or restaurant

contents.description: Exclude:

list: the costs of materials purchases for use in the installation, repair or maintenance of customers' goods
any other goods 'sold' as part of a service

definitions.title: Examples of goods bought for resale

answers.label: Expenditure on purchases of goods bought for resale
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Expenditure on goods bought for resale

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on all other goods and services?
description: State the net full delivered cost of purchases made during the period of this return whether or not they were used or resold during that period.

contents.description: Include:
Exclude:

definitions.title: Examples of other goods and services

answers.label: Expenditure on all other goods and services
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: all fuel costs, for example, electricity, gas, oil, coal, coke, petrol and diesel, purchased for use in the running of your business
purchases of water used in the running of your business, including water extraction charges
sewerage charges and other costs of effluent and waste disposal
other goods and materials, such as office materials, for example, stationery and consumables, machine spares and packaging materials charged to you
the cost of goods and materials purchased for use in the installation, repair or maintenance of customers’ goods
payments for hiring, leasing or renting plant, machinery and vehicles, if acquired under operational leases, but not if purchased under hire purchase or finance leasing arrangements
amounts payable to other organisations for transport
road transport services purchased for own staff us, for example, buses and taxis
purchases of computer and related services, including consultancy charges on computer software and hardware and the cost of repair, maintenance and installation of office and computing machinery
payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
amounts, except those charged to the capital account payable to others for the services of accountants, auditors, agents, solicitors and surveyors
amounts payable to other organisations and self-employed persons, for example, for labour they have supplied
amounts payable for the right to use patents, trade marks, copyrights and so on, manufacturing rights and technical know-how
amounts payable to other organisations for technical research and studies
amounts payable for sea, air and rail freight on goods transported
building repairs, maintenance and contract cleaning services
payments to other businesses within the same group, for example, service companies
rent paid on buildings or dwellings
amounts paid for licensing, inspection and monitoring
travelling and subsistence expenses for individual claims
congestion charges including related fines and penalties
the cost of any materials you have supplied for work done by you as a subcontractor
the cost of materials purchased for use in the installation, repair or maintenance of customers’ goods
rental of telephone handsets and modems
purchase of telephone handsets and modems
payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
payments for film and programme right
exam costs and amounts payable for training packages
insurance costs which are passed on to the customer
any other goods or services purchased
management fees and/or inter group charges

contents.description: Exclude:

list: all bank and other interest payments
any allowances for depreciation, amortisation or obsolescence including future provisions
cost of any item charged to the capital account including building repairs
fines and penalties except those related to congestion charges
amounts charged to capital account including computer hardware, software and programs written by a third party to be used for more than one year
carcasses purchased in order to produce smaller cuts of meat
mortgage interest and mortgage loan payments

blocks.page_title: Expenditure on all other goods and services

blocks.title: We have calculated your business's total expenditure on energy, goods, materials and services, during the reporting period, to be %(total)s. Is this correct?

calculation.title: Total expenditure on energy, goods, material and services

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the Government?
description: You should only include the value for the rates, duties, levies and taxes listed below if your business paid these directly to government, statutory bodies or regulators. Do not include these taxes if they were paid as part of your purchase of goods, materials and services.

contents.description: Include:

list: Vehicle Excise Duty also known as road, car or vehicle tax

Climate Change Levy (CCL), introduced in April 2001, is charged on industrial and commercial use of various forms of energy. For example, primary and secondary fuel for lighting, heating, motive power, and power for appliances

contents.description: Exclude:

list: tax already included in the purchase of goods, materials, and services
any agreed reductions on the Climate Change Levy

answers.label: Expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the Government
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: excise duties, for example, on alcohol, tobacco, hydrocarbon oil, duty, when paid directly to government by your business
any business rates or formula rates paid to local authorities or Department of Communities and Local Government (DCLG), Formula rates paid to DCLG applies to Great Britain only
export levies, for example, under the EU’s Common Agricultural Policy

regulator fees, including any statutory amounts paid to: Environment Agency (EA), Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (OFGEM), Office of Water Service Regulation (OFWAT) in England and Wales and the Scottish Water and Sewerage Customers Council (SWSCC) in Scotland, Office of Communications (OFCOM) and Office of Rail and Road (ORR)
franchise payments to government, for example, rail franchise premia
sugar levy paid to the European Union
levies paid to government levy-funded bodies, for example, Financial Services Compensation Scheme, Agriculture & Horticulture Development Board, Sea Fish Industry Authority and so on
CRC Energy Efficiency Scheme, formerly known as Carbon Reduction Commitment
Vehicle Registration Tax, paid upon registering new or imported vehicle for the first time

contents.description: Exclude:

list: net payments to trade associations and similar bodies
stamp duties paid on the purchases of shared by broker on behalf of their clients
fees and other licences such as for passports, television, boating and fishing
Council Tax payable via local authorities in respect of your rented property

blocks.page_title: Expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes

summary.page_title: Value of stocks held section summary

blocks.page_title: Value of stocks held section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding the value value of all stocks at the beginning and end of the period.

list: Inventories should be valued on the basis used in your financial statements on the basis of UK GAAP (Generally Accepted Accounting Principles) or International GAAP.
Where long-term contract balances are included in stocks, they should be recorded net of progress payments.
Where the outcome of the contract is known with reasonable certainty and a proportion of the contract income has been recognised as turnover, progress payments should be disregarded.

contents.description: This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

This refers to goods and services that have been partially processed, fabricated, or assembled by the producer but that are not usually sold or turned over to others without further processing. These products include Work in Progress belonging to the unit, even if the products in question are in the possession of third parties.

Equally, products held by the unit which belong to third parties are excluded, as are partially completed structures for which the ultimate owner is deemed to have taken ownership, either by the existence of a contract of sale or purchase, or because the production is for own use.

title.text: What was {ru_name}'s total value of all stocks on {from}?

description: The figures for the beginning and end of the period should be on the same basis in terms of valuation and business units covered.

contents.description: Include:

list: all stocks that you own title to, of goods and materials on hand for sale or processing, other than goods supplied to another party with a reservation of title clause if treated as turnover
all stocks owned and held by you in the UK or currently in transit within the UK
all stocks owned and held by you overseas or currently in transit abroad
the value of any goods let out on hire, only if they were charged to current account when acquired and do not rank as capital items for taxation purposes
products that you own title to in intermediate stages of completion
duty on stocks held out of bond
long term business contract balances with progress payments treated in line with UK GAAP or International GAAP
contracts not yet finalised - commission fees for work carried out
building work carried out by yourselves, including finished properties built by yourselves, with the intention to sell

contents.description: Exclude:

list: stocks you hold but do not own title to including consignment stock
duty on stocks held in bond
products in intermediate stages of completion that do not belong to you

label.text: Total value of all stocks on {from}

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Total value of all stocks at the beginning of the period

title.text: What was your business's total value of all stocks on {to}?

description: The figures for the beginning and end of the period should be on the same basis in terms of valuation and business units covered.

contents.description: Include:

list: all stocks that you own title to, of goods and materials on hand for sale or processing, other than goods supplied to another party with a reservation of title clause if treated as turnover
all stocks owned and held by you in the UK or currently in transit within the UK
all stocks owned and held by you overseas or currently in transit abroad
the value of any goods let out on hire, only if they were charged to current account when acquired and do not rank as capital items for taxation purposes
products that you own title to in intermediate stages of completion
duty on stocks held out of bond
long term business contract balances with progress payments treated in line with UK GAAP or International GAAP
contracts not yet finalised - commission fees for work carried out
building work carried out by yourselves, including finished properties built by yourselves, with the intention to sell

contents.description: Exclude:

list: stocks you hold but do not own title to including consignment stock
duty on stocks held in bond
products in intermediate stages of completion that do not belong to you

answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

blocks.page_title: Total value of all stocks at the end of the period
Capital assets section

contents.description: This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.
Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s total value of capital assets acquired and disposed of?

description: Provide values for acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

contents.description: Include:

list: land and land improvements or preparation, for own use
other natural resources and non-produced assets, for example, subsoil assets, crude oil, coal, water abstraction and so on
non-produced assets, for example, goodwill, patents, licences, concessions, contracts, trade dress, mastheads, domain names, collective and certification marks
existing buildings and structures for own use or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
major refurbishment, newly built and construction work for own use
construction of structures such as oil wells, platforms, mines, pipes, power lines, transport infrastructure, wind farms, turbines, and steel frameworks

transport assets and equipment, for example, new and used vehicles, special purpose vehicles, trailers, ships, boats, aircraft, and railway rolling stock, motorcycles, bicycles, parts, accessories, and major repairs
computers and hardware devices, for example, printers, servers, monitors, keyboards, and terminals
telecommunication equipment, for example, phones, fax machines, switchboards, transmitters, CCTV equipment, TV cameras, and burglar or fire alarms
fabricated products, for example, textile, leather, plastic, and metal products
intellectual property assets, for example, recordings, films and performances, manuscripts and publications, plans, instructions, and designs
transfer costs, professional charges, contracts and fees, for example, surveyors' fees, stamp duty, taxes and legal costs

contents.description: Exclude:

list: structures that are used primarily as residences
utilities such as gas, electricity and water
costs of ongoing management of computer software and databases
works of art, for example, paintings and sculptures, even if acquired or disposed of by dealers, galleries or museums
revaluations of assets, for example, depreciation, amortisation and impairment charges

answers.label: Value of capital assets from acquisitions
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

answers.label: Value of capital assets from disposals

contents.description: Include:

list: assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provision of services, for more than one year
the purchase costs and disposal proceeds of fixed assets, together with any other amounts treated as capital items for taxation purposes
the total capital value of assets that have been bought on hire purchase in the period covered by the survey
assets acquired under finance lease transfers where you, the lessee, are responsible for repairs and maintenance
assets owned by the business but leased to another business under an operating lease where you, the lessor, are responsible for repairs and maintenance
any trade or transfer costs invoiced to you separately
expenditure on replacing assets destroyed in circumstances, for example fire, which have given rise to a successful insurance claim
expenditure on assets acquired for hiring, renting and other leasing purposes, but not finance leasing
capital expenditure at any site belonging to the business where operations have not yet begun
grants and allowances from government sources, statutory bodies or local authorities that have been used to acquire or create assets used in production
finance relating to Public Private Partnership or Private Finance Initiative that has been used to acquire assets
progress payment or deposits covering long-term contracts acquiring fixed assets
all work of a capital nature carried out by your own staff, including labour costs and the cost of purchases consumed in work
professional charges, installation costs and so on, associated with capital assets must be reported with the asset value

contents.description: Exclude:

list: assets acquired in taking over an existing business or sold as part of a going concern
assets of a capital nature acquired for resale rather than for use within business, for example, stocks of vehicles held by motor traders
assets like TV adverts or copyrights
software licences of up to a year
assets leased to another business under finance lease where repair and maintenance are carried out by the other business, or lessee
assets acquired under an operating lease where responsibility for repair and maintenance is borne by the owner, or lessor, of the asset
asset transfers between companies owned by the same enterprise, except where the asset value is considered to be a 'new' acquisition or disposal within the company accounts
interest and instalment payments under finance leasing arrangements
capital expenditure on assets for use outside the UK, except ships and aircraft
allowances for depreciation, amortisation and impairment charges
the proceeds from an insurance claim against the loss of fixed assets

blocks.page_title: Value of capital assets

summary.page_title: International trade in services section summary

blocks.page_title: International trade in services section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: Of {ru_name}'s total turnover for the period {from} to {to}, what was your business's income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK?

description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man. A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.

Please provide examples of services provided by individuals, enterprises or other organisations outside of the UK in the comments box at the end of the questionnaire.

contents.description: Include:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK

contents.description: Exclude:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
transactions in financial assets or liabilities
repairs other than for construction equipment and computers
salaries of staff seconded abroad, if the period of their absence is more than one year
business travel services, such as accommodation and meals, whilst abroad

definitions.title: Examples of 'services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations'

list: repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance or any other repairs
the hiring out of plant, machinery and other goods such as operational leasing
advertising and commission as an agent, excluding the value of imports or exports of good

answers.label: Income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

Research and Development section

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's Research and Development.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: Did {ru_name} carry out any in-house Research and Development for the period {from} to {to}, or intend to do so in the next reporting period?

description: Base your answer on business activity within the UK.

definitions.title: What we mean by 'Research and Development'

contents.description: Research and Development covers three types of activity:

R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - To be aimed at new findings
Creative - To be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - To be uncertain about the final outcome
Systematic - To be planned and budgeted
Transferable or reproducible - To lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

blocks.page_title: In-house Research and Development activities

question.title: Please provide any further details that will help us understand your figures and tell an industry story
description:
'Explain any changes in your figures from your previous return, including any negative figures you need to report. If you provide comments, we are less likely to contact you with data queries.

Make sure you continue to the next page and select 'submit answers' at the bottom.

contents.description: Please include details of:
Any significant impacts upon your data resulting from changes to your business. For example:
Changes in the accounting approaches you have taken. For example:

list: change of accounting standard such as IFRS
